author: Achieng

objective: NA

author: Arrive
title: HIV status disclosure and retention in care in HIV-infected adolescents on antiretroviral therapy (ART) in West Africa
objective: NA

author: Barton
title: Cost-effectiveness of nurse-led versus doctor-led antiretroviral treatment in South Africa: pragmatic cluster randomised trial
objective: NA

author: Batavia
title: Adherence to antiretroviral therapy in patients participating in a graduated cost recovery program at an HIV care center in South India
objective: NA
behav_target_desc: medication adherence.  Implementation target is vaguely referred to, mostly this reflects my own interpreatation.
imp_action_desc: Cost restructuring, not clearly described.  Dose is roughly based on income level, but this is not clearly described.

author: Alamo
title: Electronic medical records and same day patient tracing improves clinic effi ciency and adherence to appointments in a community based HIV/AIDS care program, in Uganda
citation: Alamo ST, Wagner GJ, Sunday P, et al. Electronic medical records and same day patient tracing improves clinic effi ciency and adherence to appointments in a community based HIV/AIDS care program, in Uganda. AIDS Behav 2012; 16: 368–74.
objective: To evaluate the impact of Electronic Medical Records (EMR) and same day patient tracing on missed clinic appointments
intervention: Electronic medical record and same-day patient tracing
comparator: pre- implementation of EMR and daily patient tracing
imp_target_comment: Same-day reminders for those who miss addresses forgetfulness; reduced wait times reduces time barrier to clinic attendance.
imp_action_desc: EMR, generation of clinic schedule, same-day identification of patients who miss an appointment, CHW home visit for missed visits, patient allowed return if same-day but penalized (seen last) if return on a different day
imp_outcome_comment: Measured reasons for missed appointment pre/post intervention - reduction in 'forgetfulness'.  Wait times also measured.
interv_name_text: EMR + same-day tracing for missed appointments

author: Assefa
title: Effectiveness and acceptability of delivery of antiretroviral treatment in health centres by health officers and nurses in Ethiopia
journal: Journal of health services research & policy
citation: Assefa Y, Kiflie A, Tekle B, Mariam DH, Laga M, Van Damme W. Effectiveness and acceptability of delivery of antiretroviral treatment in health centres by health officers and nurses in Ethiopia. Journal of health services research & policy 2012;17(1):24–9.
objective: to evaluate the effectiveness and acceptability of ART delivery by health officers and nurses in Ethiopia.
intervention: Patients initiated and maintained at health centres by nurses and health officers. Severe manifestations, treatment failures were referred to hospital
comparator: Initiated and followed up at hospital with physicians
study_comments: number of patients not reported, n is number of clinics & hospitals

author: Balcha
title: Outcomes of antiretroviral treatment: a comparison between hospitals and health centers in Ethiopia
journal: Journal of the International association of Physicians in AIDS Care
citation: Balcha TT, Jeppsson A. Outcomes of antiretroviral treatment: a comparison between hospitals and health centers in Ethiopia. Journal of the International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care (Chicago, Ill. : 2002) 2010;9(5): 318–24.
objective: to compare the outcomes of antiretroviral therapy (ART) between hospital and health center levels in Ethiopia
iecriteria: Adults eligible for antiretroviral treatment (CD4 <200cell/mm3 or WHO clinical stage 3 or 4) and on treatment for < 6 months
intervention: Initiation on antiretrovirals in health centre, maintenance in health centre; provided by nurses and health officers
comparator: Initiated and maintained in hospital, provided by doctors
behav_target_desc: Target not specified.  Cascade step is retention, grossly defined as remaining alive and in clinic.
imp_target_comment: Reduce barrier of distance to clinic/transportation costs in time and money.
imp_action_desc: "decentralization" not defined as a clear action in this study - compares outcomes among patients at central vs. decentralized sites thus it is not clear if the action is to open new clinics, guide patients to these new clinics etc.
imp_outcome_comment: Distance to clinic, reduction in barriers to travel to clinic were not measured.
interv_name_text: 'Decentralization', though as mentioned above, this is not a clear intervention

author: Bassett
title: Linkage to care following community-based mobile HIV testing compared with clinic-based testing in Umlazi Township, Durban, South Africa
citation: Bassett, I., Regan, S., Luthuli, P., Mbonambi, H., Bearnot, B., Pendleton, A., Robine, M., Mukuvisi, D., Thulare, H., Walensky, R., Freedberg, K., Losina, E. and Mhlongo, B. (2013), Linkage to care following community-based mobile HIV testing compared wit
objective: to compare linkage to care from mobile and clinic-based testing sites
intervention: mobile testing with immediate CD4 draw
comparator: clinic testing with immediate CD4 draw
study_comments: potential problems with record linkage - only 33% of mobile testers had blood drawn for CD4, unclear how individuals were identified who later returned to clinic for CD4 testing
cas_comments: No denominator for testing.  Linkage and staging are conflated.
behav_target_desc: Waiting for CD4 blood draw, clinic attendance following HIV diagnosis
imp_action_desc: Mobile testing offered at various locations by HIV counselors.  Conducted under tents with on-site plebotomy
imp_outcome_comment: Behavioral outcomes measured include waiting for blood draw and clinic attendance following positive test.

author: Bedelu
title: Implementing antiretroviral therapy in rural communities: the Lusikisiki model of decentralized HIV/AIDS care
citation: BedeluM, Ford N,Hilderbrand K, Reuter H. Implementing antiretroviral therapy in rural communities: the Lusikisiki model of decentralized HIV/AIDS care. The Journal of infectious diseases 2007;196 Suppl 3:S464–8.
objective: to compare the outcomes of antiretroviral therapy (ART) between hospital and decentralized health center levels
iecriteria: adults initiating ART (CD4<200 or WHO stage 4)
intervention: ART initiated and maintained at health centre by nurses, physician support with mobile team, adherence counsellors and patient support groups available
comparator: ART initiated and maintained at hospital by doctors
behav_target_desc: Roughly speaking, the behavior targeted by this intervention is at the clinic level and is to "retain" patients in clinical care.  The behavior that is involved in retaining patients at the clinic level is not clearly defined.
imp_target_comment: The authors assert that the major driving force toward the ill-defined behavioral target is clinic capability - through decentralization and task shifting, clinics are better able to deliver services.
imp_action_desc: decentralization of HIV services to other clinics, task shifting to nurses and mobile visits by physicians are described. However, the roles of the actual actors carrying out 'decentralization' are not described.

author: Bock
title: Provision of antiretroviral therapy to children within the public sector of South Africa
journal: Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg
citation: Bock P, Boulle A, White C, Osler M, Eley B. Provision of antiretroviral therapy to children within the public sector of South Africa. Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene 2008;102(9):905–11.
setting: Urban, peri-urban, 20 health centres (enhanced), 16 hospitals, 3 advanced hospitals
objective: To compare clinical outcomes of children treated for HIV infection at primary healthcare clinics, district hospitals, and secondary and tertiary hospital
iecriteria: All children <15 years starting ART.  Eligibility for ART (modified WHO stage 2, 3 disease, or low CD4% by age group - <20% if <18 months old, or <15% if >18 months old, or recurrent hospitalisation >4 weeks, and identifiable caregiver)
intervention: Intervention 1 (Primary health care clinics): ART initiated at advanced hospital, maintained at enhanced health centres, by doctors; Intervention 2 (Level 1 district hospitals): ART initiated at advanced hospital, maintained at hospital, by doctors
comparator: Control (level 2 and 3 facilities): ART initiated and maintained at advanced hospital, by doctors and specialists
behav_target_desc: Similar to other decentralization interventions, the level of the behavioral target is the health center.  By delivering HIV care in smaller facilities, systems aim to improve retention, however the actual intended behavior is not specified.
imp_target_comment: Though intervention targets could be imagined, none are mentioned.

author: Brennan
title: Outcomes of stable HIV-positive patients down-referred from a doctor-managed antiretroviral therapy clinic to a nurse-managed primary health clinic for monitoring and treatment
citation: Brennan AT, Long L, Maskew M, et al. Outcomes of stable HIV-positive patients down-referred from a doctor-managed antiretroviral therapy clinic to a nurse-managed primary health clinic for monitoring and treatment. AIDS 2011; 25: 2027–36.
objective: To compare clinical, immunologic and virologic outcomes among stable HIV-positive patients down-referred to a nurse-managed primary healthcare clinic (PHC) for treatment maintenance to those who remained at a doctor-managed treatment-initiation site.
iecriteria: patients who met criteria for down-referral (undetectable viral load <10 months, antiretroviral therapy (ART) >11 months, CD4 cell count 200 cells/ml, stable weight and no opportunistic infections)
intervention: down-referral from doctor-managed treatment site to local nurse-managed primary care clinic
behav_target_desc: attend clinic appointments - though this is not clearly defined (because loss to follow-up is included as the converse of this behavior.
imp_target_comment: decreased waiting time, decreased travel time, increased patient satisfaction
imp_action_desc: down-referral - specific eligibility criteria and process for down-referral (provider reminder and electronic transfer of patient data)
imp_meas_comment: Proportion of eligible patients who were actually down-referred was reported.  A citation to a separate paper using the same cohort also discusses cost-effectiveness of down-referral.
imp_outcome_comment: Data presented in discussion suggesting that wait time is reduced at decentralized sites, but no primary data presented

author: Brentlinger
title: Task shifting in Mozambique: cross-sectional evaluation of non-physician clinicians’ performance in HIV/AIDS care
citation: Brentlinger P, Assan A, Mudender F, et al. Task shifting in Mozambique: cross-sectional evaluation of non-physician clinicians’ performance in HIV/AIDS care. Hum Resour Health 2010; 8: 23.
setting: public-sector health facilities in which the TM participants normally practiced
objective: To evaluate the quality of care delivered by non-physician clinicians after a two-week in-service training course emphasizing antiretroviral therapy (ART).

intervention: two-week training on ART, co-trimoxazole prophylaxis, and lesser emphasis on clinical staging and Ois

author: Burtle
title: Introduction and evaluation of a 'pre-ART care' service in Swaziland: an operational research study.
citation: Burtle D, Welfare W, Elden S, Mamvura C, Vandelanotte J, Petherick E, et al. Introduction and evaluation of a 'pre-ART care' service in Swaziland: an operational research study. BMJ Open. 2012; 2(2): e000195.
program: Good Shepherd Hospital - a district referral hospital
objective: To implement and evaluate a formal pre-antiretroviral therapy (ART) care service at a district hospital in Swaziland.
iecriteria: did not include data from new testers, those who were pregnant or were known to be co-infected with TB.
intervention: Introduction of pre-ART careda package of interventions, including counselling; regular review; clinical staging; timely initiation of ART; social and
comparator: Baseline care: HIV care prior to commencing ART was episodic

author: Cantrell
title: A Pilot Study of Food Supplementation to Improve Adherence to Antiretroviral Therapy Among Food-Insecure Adults in Lusaka, Zambia
objective: To evaluate the effect of food supplementation on adherence to antiretroviral therapy among food insecure adults initiating ART in Lusaka, Zambia.
iecriteria: Food insecure adults participating in a home based adherence program
cas_comments: Medication Possession Ratio - more retention than adherence in my opinion.
behav_target_desc: Return to clinic for pharmacy refill
imp_target_comment: Increased energy/health to attend clinic.  Increased motivation to collect food supplement to support individual and family nutrition.
imp_action_desc: Action changed during intervention period - initially quantity of food given determined by primary earner status, later determined by household size.  However, both proceses are explained, including the manner in which eligiblity is assessed and food is d

author: Chan
title: Outcome assessment of decentralization of antiretroviral therapy provision in a rural district of Malawi using an integrated primary care model
citation: Chan AK, Mateyu G, Jahn A, Schouten E, Arora P, Mlotha W, et al. Outcome assessment of decentralization of antiretroviral therapy provision in a rural district of Malawi using an integrated primary care model. Tropical medicine & international health : TM
objective: To assess the effect of decentralization (DC) of antiretroviral therapy (ART) provision in a rural district of Malawi using an integrated primary care model.
iecriteria: Adults and older children initiating ART.
intervention: Receiving follow-up at decentralized site or initiating ART at decentralized site. Prior to Apr 2008, all patients initiated ART at central site and were decentralized for ART follow-up from the mother clinic (ZCH) to a health centre if they met several c
comparator: Initiating ART and receiving follow-up at central site
study_comments: only 1005/3440 patients included as "decentralized" actually initiated ART at decentralized site.  Remainder initiated at hospital and transferred because they were stable.
behav_target_desc: Target behavior is retention in care (different set of behaviors than the measured outcome of retention in clinic)
imp_action_desc: Authors describe a model for decentralized primary care, however the action of 'decentralization' is not actuallly defined.

author: Chandisarewa
title: Routine offer of antenatal HIV testing (‘‘opt-out’’ approach) to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV in urban Zimbabwe.
objective: Effect of opt out on HIV testing in pregnant women

author: Chang
title: Effect of peer health workers on AIDS care in Rakai, Uganda: a cluster-randomized trial.
citation: Chang LW, Kagaayi J, Nakigozi G, Ssempijja V, Packer AH, Serwadda D, et al. Effect of peer health workers on AIDS care in Rakai, Uganda: a cluster-randomized trial. PLoS One. 2010; 5(6): e10923.
objective: Our primary hypothesis was that, compared to patients in control communities, patients on ART in communities with PHWs will have improved adherence and fewer virologic failures.
iecriteria: all adult patients at the 15 mobile clinic sites who were either already on ART at the start of the trial or were started on ART at any time during the trial.
imp_action_desc: Peer health worker community-based adherence counseling, pill counts, review of symptoms and clinic referralss.
imp_meas_comment: Feasibility based on pilot data reported separately.  Reporting on the proportion of eligible patients appraoched, acceptance rate of the intervention, mean number of visits per patient and mean number of visits per health worker.

author: Chi
title: Expanded services for the prevention of mother-to-child HIV transmission: field acceptability of a pilot program in Lusaka, Zambia
citation: Chi BH, Chintu N, Lee A, Stringer EM, Sinkala M & Stringer AJS (2007) Expanded services for the prevention of mother-to-child HIV transmission: field acceptability of a pilot program in Lusaka, Zambia. Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes 45, 1
objective: To evaluate a pilot program designed to link PMTCT services to long-term HIV care and treatment in Lusaka, Zambia.
iecriteria: All women newly diagnosed with HIV in ANC
intervention: Linkage procedures: scripted talk on benefits of long-term HIV care and importance of CD4 screening, encouragement to enroll in HIV care, escort by CHW to on-site HIV facility for enrollment

author: Choun
title: Timing of antiretroviral therapy in Cambodian hospital after diagnosis of tuberculosis: impact of revised WHO guidelines
objective: The main objective of this study was to assess the change in time to ART initiation following the implementation of the 2010 WHO ART guidelines in a programmatic setting in a resource-limited area.
iecriteria: We included in the study all ART-naïve HIV-positive adults who initiated antituberculosis treatment as inpatients or outpatients over the 18 months that preceded and the 18 months that followed the implementation of the 2010 WHO guidelines in June 2010
intervention: Guideline change; Communication Weekly medical department meeting (TB and HIV physicians) Monthly multidisciplinary meeting of key HIV and TB care staff to discuss logistical, managerial, operational issues
behav_target_desc: Target behavior is analyzed at the level of the health center.  The behavior of interest is compliance of the guideline to initiate ART within 8 weeks of TB treatment initiation.  Retention pre/post initiation is also evaluated, but as a secondary outcome
imp_target_comment: Though not specified in these terms, the implication of guideline implementation in this paper is that the external environment is altered at the health center level, allowing providers/clinics to initiate patients on ART earlier.
imp_action_desc: Implementation of WHO guidelines.  Box 2 in manuscript dedicated to discussing 'dose', that is the activities and their frequency/intensity that were carried out to ensure effective guideline implementation.
imp_meas_comment: Primary focus of the study is adoption of the guidelines.
imp_outcome_comment: Study was not able to measure the reasons for failure to initiate ART within the 8-week window - patient refusal would lead to different conclusions than provider attitudes about safety of guidelines, problems with toxicity or other reasons.

author: Christie
title: Paediatric and perinatal HIV/AIDS in Jamaica an international leadership initiative, 2002–2007
citation: Christie CD, Steel-Duncan J, Palmer P, Pierre R, Harvey K, Johnson N et al. Paediatric and perinatal HIV/AIDS in Jamaica an international leadership initiative, 2002–2007. West Indian Med J 2008;57:204–15. PMID:19583118
objective: to address the paediatric and perinatal HIV/AIDS epidemic in Jamacia
iecriteria: All women starting ANC in 3 included cities
intervention: Leadership and collaborative education initiative among academic and government healthcare personel
study_comments: very descriptive, only included in matrix because some specific info is provided about broad leadership/training initiative for health care providers to tackle issue of PMTCT

author: Chung
title: Chung MH, Richardson BA, Tapia K, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing the eff ects of counseling and alarm device on HAART adherence and virologic outcomes. PLoS Med 2011; 8: e1000422.
citation: Chung MH, Richardson BA, Tapia K, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing the eff ects of counseling and alarm device on HAART adherence and virologic outcomes. PLoS Med 2011; 8: e1000422.
objective: To evaluate the effect of adherence counseling and/or electronic pill reminder on treatment success
iecriteria: HIV-infected adults (>=18) who were initiating ART, antiretroviral naive, agreed to home visits, and planned to live in Kenya for at least 2 y.
intervention: Adherence counseling - 2 sessions prior to ART initiation and 1 session one month post-initiation (arm 1), electronic pill reminder (arm 2), both counseling and reminder (arm 3)
cas_comments: monthly pill count.  Initiation and retention on ART reported in Figure 1, but not formally tested.
imp_target_comment: Counseling focused on patient knowledge/skills and motivation to adhere.  Reminder device acts as augmentation of patient skills/motivation.
imp_action_desc: Counseling - 2 pre-initiation sessions & 1 post-initiation session, followed script.  Delivered by "trained counselors" - training or experience not specified.
imp_meas_comment: Proportion of participants undergoing 1, 2 and 3 counseling sessions is reported.  Self-reported length of alarm use and reasons for non-use reported.

author: Ciampa
title: Addressing Poor Retention of Infants Exposed to HIV: A Quality Improvement Study in Rural Mozambique

intervention: 2 phases of improvement using quality improvement methods. In phase 1, we enhanced referral by offering direct accompaniment of new mothers to the EID suite, increasing privacy, and opening a medical record for infants before postpartum discharge. In phas
comparator: Process of EID referral at baseline

author: Ciampa
title: Improving retention in the early infant diagnosis of HIV program in rural Mozambique by better service integration
citation: Ciampa PJ, Burlison JR, Blevins M, et al. Improving retention in the early infant diagnosis of HIV program in rural Mozambique by better service integration. J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. Sep 1 2011;58(1):115-119.
objective: effect of a structural intervention to enhance referral to EID on proportion of HIV-exposed infants who return for HIV testing and continued monitoring.
iecriteria: All HIV-infected women who gave birth to a live infant at a study hospital from September 2009 until June 2010 were included along with their infants.
intervention: enhanced EID referral by maternity nurses before discharge; directly accompanied by a maternity nurse before discharge to the location of EID services within the hospital grounds

author: Corbett
title: Uptake of workplace HIV counselling and testing: a cluster-randomised trial in Zimbabwe.
citation: Corbett EL, Dauya E, Matambo R, et al. Uptake of workplace HIV counselling and testing: a cluster-randomised trial in Zimbabwe. PLoS Med. Jul 2006;3(7):e238.
objective: investigated the impact of rapid HIV testing at the workplace on uptake of voluntary counselling and testing (VCT).
intervention: on-site rapid HIV testing at their occupational clinic
comparator: vouchers for off-site VCT at a chain of free-standing centres also using rapid tests
imp_target_comment: Discussion briefly mentions reductions in barriers to testing as a possible mechanism, based on findings from other studies.
imp_action_desc: lack of clarity regarding action for comparison - referral for outside testing with rapid test with 2-wk follow up to review results.  Uncear why follow-up results review appt was needed.  For dose, available hours and intensity of offer was not specified
imp_meas_comment: Adoption of participation in offer to test is derived from proportion participating in study.  May not be fully representative of adoption in a real world setting.

author: Etienne
title: Situational analysis of varying models of adherence support and loss to follow up rates; findings from 27 treatment facilities in eight resource limited countries
objective: To evaluate effect of adherence support models on loss to follow up
intervention: One of 4 adherence support strategies: adherence cousneling, structured treatment preparation, home visits, community health worker
behav_target_desc: Loss to follow-up is not a behavior, however could consider return to the index clinic for provider visit and/or drug refill as the target behavior
interv_name_text: Four tiers of 'adherence support' include adherence counselling, structured treatment preparation, community home visits, supportive supervision by community nurse

author: Faal
title: Providing Immediate CD4 Count Results at HIV Testing Improves ART Initiation
setting: at an urban primary health care clinic (Esselen clinic) in the inner city of Johannesburg
objective: This study evaluated the impact of providing a CD4 count result at HIV diagnosis or written information on enrolment into pre-ART or ART care in a large urban primary health care clinic in Johannesburg.
iecriteria: adults older than 18 years who had already received pretest counseling and were awaiting HIV testing. Patients were excluded if they were pregnant as their options for further care was based on higher CD4 count cut-offs. Patients who had WHO stage IV clin
intervention: Intervention: blood for CD4 count was drawn at the time of testing and the patient received the result on the same day
comparator: Control A: blood for CD4 count was drawn at the time of testing, patients were required to return to receive the result  Control B: blood for CD4 count was drawn at the time of testing, patients were required to return to receive the result, but they rece

imp_meas_comment: No information about adoption, fidelity, etc is offered.  For example, patients were required to wait for 45 minutes after HIV diagnosis to receive their CD4 results - did all of them wait?  What proportion actually received results on the same day?

author: Fairall
title: Task shifting of antiretroviral treatment from doctors to primary-care nurses in South Africa (STRETCH): a pragmatic, parallel, cluster-randomised trial

objective: Mortality among eligible patients not on ART
intervention: STRETCH intervention - task shifting to nurses to start and refill ART.
exclude_reason: no cascade outcome (outcome VL or death)

author: Farquhar
title: Antenatal couple counseling increases uptake of interventions to prevent HIV-1 transmission.
